bestBHT.bht: They bring him to the place of Golgotha, or the place of a skull, as Golgotha means skull and Luke refers to it as such. This name may have been given to the location due to its conical shape resembling a skull. Golgotha was infamous for its many executions, with scattered skulls of the deceased being visible. It is at this notable site where Jesus was crucified and where his garments were divided among the soldiers. Matthew, Luke, and John also mention this significant event.

Henry Alford: 22.] the place Golgotha—or perhaps the place of Golgotha, as the word Golgotha would then answer to a skull in the interpretation; St. Luke has “the place which is called a skull.”
Philip Schaff: To the place Golgotha. More correctly perhaps: place of Golgotha, answering to Place of a Skull, since Golgotha means ‘skull,’ and Luke (Luke 23:33) calls the place simply ‘skull.’
This is an additional reason for supposing that the name was owing to the conical shape of the ground.
Archibald T. Robertson: They bring him (φερουσιν αυτον). Historical present again. See on Matthew 27:33 for discussion of Golgotha.
John Gill: A famous, or rather an infamous one, well known, and much noted for the many executions there
The skulls of men that had been executed and buried there, being dug up again, lay scattered about
John Wesley: Matthew 27:33; Luke 23:33; John 19:1724,25. St. Mark seems to intimate, that they first nailed him to the cross, then parted his garments, and afterward reared up the cross.

bhtAttempts.bht: They bring him to the place of Golgotha, also known as the place of a skull. This name is fitting, as Golgotha means skull, and Luke simply calls it skull. Perhaps the name comes from the conical shape of the ground, which resembled a skull. This infamous place was well known for its many executions, and the skulls of those who had been executed and buried there could be seen scattered about. It is at this location that Jesus was nailed to the cross, his garments were divided, and the cross was erected. Matthew, Luke, and John also mention this significant event.

It is at this notable site where Jesus was crucified and where his garments were divided among the soldiers. Matthew, Luke, and John also mention this significant event.
